articles.headline: Colbert Will Host ‘Late Show,’ Playing Himself for a Change
articles.snippet: Stephen Colbert became the immediate front-runner for the position both because of an increasing recognition of his talent and because he clearly wanted the job.
articles.abstract: Stephen Colbert became the immediate front-runner for the position both because of an increasing recognition of his talent and because he clearly wanted the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: CBS made its choice, quickly and definitively: Stephen Colbert will succeed David Letterman as the host of its late-night franchise, which Mr. Letterman created when he came to the network in 1993.

articles.headline: Judge Approves SAC Plea, Closing a Painful Chapter
articles.snippet: The agreement with federal prosecutors requires the once-mighty hedge fund run by Steven A. Cohen to pay $1.2 billion to the government while shutting its doors to outside investors.
articles.abstract: The agreement with federal prosecutors requires the once-mighty hedge fund run by Steven A. Cohen to pay $1.2 billion to the government while shutting its doors to outside investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:40 p.m. | In the span of a week, Steven A. Cohen’s investment firm changed its name, hired a former federal prosecutor and became a felon.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Sacrificing Sense for Speed in Markets
articles.snippet: Today’s stock markets operate at blinding speed, using bewilderingly complicated processes untempered by common sense or accountability.
articles.abstract: Today’s stock markets operate at blinding speed, using bewilderingly complicated processes untempered by common sense or accountability.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rube Goldberg: A comically involved, complicated invention, laboriously contrived to perform a seemingly simple operation.

articles.headline: Hoping for Asylum, Migrants Strain U.S. Border
articles.snippet: Those who risk a danger-filled journey across Mexico to cross the Rio Grande into Texas are now primarily from Central America.
articles.abstract: Those who risk a danger-filled journey across Mexico to cross the Rio Grande into Texas are now primarily from Central America.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIDALGO, Tex. — Border Patrol agents in olive uniforms stood in broad daylight on the banks of the Rio Grande, while on the Mexican side smugglers pulled up in vans and unloaded illegal migrants.

articles.headline: Warily, Jordan Assists Rebels in Syrian War
articles.snippet: Jordan has been quietly providing a staging ground for the rebels and their foreign backers on Syria’s southern front, but many say the aid is not enough.
articles.abstract: Jordan has been quietly providing a staging ground for the rebels and their foreign backers on Syria’s southern front, but many say the aid is not enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: IRBID, Jordan — When rebels want to return to Syria to fight, Jordan’s intelligence services give them specific times to cross its border. When the rebels need weapons, they make their request at an “operations room” in Amman staffed by agents from Jordan, Saudi Arabia and the United States.

articles.headline: Sebelius Resigns After Troubles Over Health Site
articles.snippet: Ending a stormy five-year tenure marred by the disastrous rollout of President Obama’s signature legislative achievement, Kathleen Sebelius is resigning as secretary of Health and Human Services.
articles.abstract: Ending a stormy five-year tenure marred by the disastrous rollout of President Obama’s signature legislative achievement, Kathleen Sebelius is resigning as secretary of Health and Human Services.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, is resigning, ending a stormy five-year tenure marred by the disastrous rollout of President Obama’s signature legislative achievement, the Affordable Care Act.

articles.headline: As Trading Hurts JPMorgan, Auto Loans Aid Wells Fargo
articles.snippet: The contrasting fortunes of two of the nation’s biggest banks at first glance point to the ascendancy of Main Street over Wall Street.
articles.abstract: The contrasting fortunes of two of the nation’s biggest banks at first glance point to the ascendancy of Main Street over Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:11 p.m. | The contrasting fortunes of two of the nation’s biggest banks — JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo — at first glance point to the ascendancy of Main Street over Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: In an Instant, a Bus to College Was a Fiery Trap
articles.snippet: The students in the accident were in a program in which Humboldt State University brings disadvantaged students who have been accepted to visit the campus.
articles.abstract: The students in the accident were in a program in which Humboldt State University brings disadvantaged students who have been accepted to visit the campus.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Harley Hoyt, an 18-year-old senior at Valhalla High School in San Diego County, was listening to his headphones to pass the time during the 12-hour bus ride up California’s Interstate 5 when he was catapulted forward, his face smashing against the seat in front of him.

articles.headline: Big G.O.P. Donors Stir Senate Runs
articles.snippet: Democrats in races that will help determine control of the Senate are burning through campaign cash as they fend off attacks from conservative groups.
articles.abstract: Democrats in races that will help determine control of the Senate are burning through campaign cash as they fend off attacks from conservative groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democrats in races that will help determine control of the Senate are rapidly burning through their campaign cash, whittling away their financial advantage over Republican opponents as they fend off attacks from conservative groups, according to figures released through Friday.

articles.headline: Detroit Wins Judge’s Nod for Contract Settlement
articles.snippet: A federal judge held up the bankrupt city’s settlement as an example of “the very spirit of negotiation and compromise” that he hoped other creditors would follow.
articles.abstract: A federal judge held up the bankrupt city’s settlement as an example of “the very spirit of negotiation and compromise” that he hoped other creditors would follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:38 p.m. | A federal judge on Friday approved this bankrupt city’s latest attempt to extricate itself from some long-term financial contracts that have been costing it tens of millions of dollars a year, holding up its settlement as an example of “the very spirit of negotiation and compromise” that he hoped other creditors would follow.

articles.headline: A Chance for a Market’s Wallflowers to Bloom
articles.snippet: The sell-off is providing a rare moment in the sun for so-called value investors, who focus on out-of-favor stocks with relatively low valuations.
articles.abstract: The sell-off is providing a rare moment in the sun for so-called value investors, who focus on out-of-favor stocks with relatively low valuations.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January, Seth Klarman, a billionaire who runs the Boston-based Baupost Group investment partnership, warned in his annual letter to clients that “a skeptic would have to be blind not to see bubbles inflating” and cited the “nosebleed stock market valuations” of companies like Netflix and Tesla Motors.
